title: FTSE ends winning streak as Standard Chartered suffers ratings downgrade
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 12, 2015, 12:22 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 8 mins FTSE ends winning streak as Standard Chartered suffers ratings downgrade By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 19 minutes ago 1.708 -0.016 
The FTSE 100 tumbled into the red in morning trade after recording its biggest weekly gain in four years on Friday. 
The FTSE’s eight-day winning streak came to an abrupt halt this morning, with miners coming under pressure once again. 
On Friday the blue chip index capped off a stellar week, recording its biggest weekly rise in almost four years . 
But Britain’s benchmark index slipped 41.77 points, or 0.64pc, to 6,375.49 in early morning trade on Monday. 
Rebecca O’Keeffe, of Interactive Investor, said it was “no surprise” to see markets had retreated slightly. 
“A few weeks ago, any move higher was punctuated by aggressive falls and fearful investors - so while a slight pullback may be disappointing, the moderate moves are nonetheless an indication of the improving health and strength of the market,” Ms O’Keeffe said. 
Standard Chartered (HKSE: 2888.HK - news ) was among the heaviest fallers on Monday morning, after Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) targeted the bank. In a bearish note entitled “The sack race”, the broker downgraded the investment bank to “hold”, snapping the stock’s 26pc gains recorded over the previous eight trading sessions. 
Investec said the “surge” in the share price was driven by “market enthusiasm” around reports the bank is planning to cut around 1,000 top staff . 
Ian Gordon, of Investec, cautioned: “Despite a raft of recent downgrades, consensus revenue/earnings forecasts remain far too high, in our view.” Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) fell 2.3pc to 768.6p. 
Mining stocks tumbled back into the red after Switzerland-based Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) announced plans to sell its Cobar copper mine in Australia and its Lomas Bayas mine in Chile. The miner and trading group slid 1.3pc to 127.5p. Meanwhile, Anglo American was off by 0.7pc, Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) was 0.6pc lower and Antofagasta (Other OTC: ANFGF - news ) fell 0.4pc. 
FTSE 100 engineer Rolls Royce (LSE: RR.L - news ) became the biggest casualty of the morning, down 4.4pc amid reports EU regulators are investigating whether airlines are being forced to enter anti-competitive contracts. 
Elsewhere, British Airways owner IAG was flying high after Goldman Sachs began covering the stock again, with a “buy” rating following its acquisition of Aer Lingus. 
The investment bank reckons the airline’s current valuation does not reflect its higher return and growth prospects. Shares jumped 1.1pc to 568p. 
European bourses also found themselves in the red this morning, with the exception of the German DAX up 0.2pc - as utility stocks propped up the index. The CAC fell 0.6pc, the IBEX was 0.2pc lower. * Asian markets rally as China says stock market correction 'almost over'
